citations.narrative:
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the 11
chickens.
Per this Section, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the acquisition and
disposition of animals in their possession to account for the sources of the animals and any animal transfers. The
Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for these birds and ensure that the
animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions. Correct by 12/23/24.

The Continency Plan has not been reviewed by the licensee on at least an annual basis. The last review of the
Contingency Plan was completed on 10/28/22.
Per this Section, all exhibitors must review their Continency Plan on at least an annual basis to ensure that it adequately
addresses potential emergency situations that could be detrimental to the health and well-being of the animals. The
Licensee needs to review the Contingency Plan and document the review. Correct by 12/23/24.

Two cat primary enclosures housing a total of 9 cats (1 adult and 8 kittens) were identified that were not in good repair.
The walls of the enclosures are made of a type of particle board sheets that have an outermost surface layer that is
impervious to moisture. There was damage noted in the back corner and/or sides of the walls at floor level that formed an
opening in the wall that exposed the space between the 2x4 wood framing and the wall of the adjacent enclosure. In
addition, there were several areas of the walls in both enclosures at floor level where the outermost surface layer of the
wall panels had peeled off exposing the underlying particle board layer that is not impervious to moisture.
Per this Section, primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. The two primary cat enclosures were not in good repair
due to the damaged areas of the walls and the missing outermost surface layer of the wall panels that exposed the
underlying particle board that is not impervious to moisture and cannot be effectively sanitized. The damaged areas of the
two primary enclosures need to be repaired/replaced to maintain the enclosures in good repair. Correct by 1/24/25.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed when appropriate and were provided with materials to enhance their
environment, a written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds had not
been developed/approved by the Attending Veterinarian and was not available for review at the time of the inspection.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by
12/23/24.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Licensee.
*END OF REPORT*
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
There were no records of acquisition or record of animals on hand available at the time of the inspection for the 11 
chickens. 
 
Per this Section, exhibitors shall make and maintain complete records regarding the details of the acquisition and 
disposition of animals in their possession to account for the sources of the animals and any animal transfers. The 
Licensee needs to prepare records of acquisition and a record of animals on hand for these birds and ensure that the 
animal records are kept current for all future animal acquisitions. Correct by 12/23/24. 
2.134(b) 
   
Contingency planning. 
The Continency Plan has not been reviewed by the licensee on at least an annual basis. The last review of the 
Contingency Plan was completed on 10/28/22. 
 
Per this Section, all exhibitors must review their Continency Plan on at least an annual basis to ensure that it adequately 
addresses potential emergency situations that could be detrimental to the health and well-being of the animals. The 
Licensee needs to review the Contingency Plan and document the review. Correct by 12/23/24. 
3.6(a)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
Two cat primary enclosures housing a total of 9 cats (1 adult and 8 kittens) were identified that were not in good repair. 
The walls of the enclosures are made of a type of particle board sheets that have an outermost surface layer that is 
impervious to moisture. There was damage noted in the back corner and/or sides of the walls at floor level that formed an 
opening in the wall that exposed the space between the 2x4 wood framing and the wall of the adjacent enclosure. In 
addition, there were several areas of the walls in both enclosures at floor level where the outermost surface layer of the 
wall panels had peeled off exposing the underlying particle board layer that is not impervious to moisture. 
 
Per this Section, primary enclosures must be kept in good repair. The two primary cat enclosures were not in good repair

due to the damaged areas of the walls and the missing outermost surface layer of the wall panels that exposed the 
underlying particle board that is not impervious to moisture and cannot be effectively sanitized. The damaged areas of the 
two primary enclosures need to be repaired/replaced to maintain the enclosures in good repair. Correct by 1/24/25. 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
Although the birds at the facility were socially housed when appropriate and were provided with materials to enhance their 
environment, a written plan for environmental enhancement to promote the psychological well-being of the birds had not 
been developed/approved by the Attending Veterinarian and was not available for review at the time of the inspection.  
 
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement 
to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian and must be in 
accordance with currently accepted professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference 
guides. At a minimum, the plan must address each of the following: social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, restraint devices, and exemptions. The Licensee needs to develop an environmental enrichment plan 
appropriate for the species of birds maintained and the plan must be approved by the Attending Veterinarian. Correct by 
12/23/24. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Licensee. 
 
*END OF REPORT*

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
